Yes, exactly this.

To elaborate on why this is: It's an unfortunate requirement of function resolution. All implementation functions for features need to ultimately be held by the same class \(the physics engine plugin class\), so each function needs a unique name. If we used the name `SetVelocity()` for setting the link velocity, then it might collide with a `SetVelocity()` for setting a joint velocity. The physics plugins may have to implement \(i.e. override\) an arbitrary collection of virtual functions from features, so it’s important that we give them very explicit names to avoid ambiguity. If two features ever have implementation functions that share the same name, then those two features cannot be used together in the same physics engine plugin.
